speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me, when did you first start experiencing symptoms of diarrhea, and how long have you been experiencing them?

speaker: Patient
text: I think it started about 24 hours ago, and since then, I've had at least 9 episodes, with each episode lasting around 30 minutes to an hour, and they've been quite frequent.

speaker: Doctor
text: How long have you been experiencing abdominal pain or discomfort associated with these episodes of diarrhea, and have you noticed any blood or mucus in your stool?

speaker: Patient
text: The pain started right around the same time as the diarrhea, about 24 hours ago, and it's been constant since then, getting a bit worse with each episode. I haven't noticed any blood in my stool, but I did have some cramping during the episodes, which is quite uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've traveled recently or consumed anything unusual in the past 24 hours that might be contributing to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: I did have a cup of coffee this morning, and I also had a salad for lunch yesterday, but I don't think that would cause this. I also haven't traveled anywhere recently, but I did pick up some fresh berries from the market on my way home from work.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the berries you picked up from the market? Were they fresh, and did you wash them before consuming them? And, have you taken any medications or supplements recently that might be affecting your digestive system?

speaker: Patient
text: I picked up the berries from a local market, and they were definitely fresh. I washed them before putting them in the fridge, but I didn't think twice about it afterwards. As for medications, I was just taking levofloxacin for pneumonia, and that's the only thing I've been taking recently.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the levofloxacin you've been taking? How long were you on it, and have you noticed any side effects that might be related to your digestive system? Also, I'd like to examine your abdomen to see if I can find any signs of inflammation or tenderness.

speaker: Patient
text: I've been taking levofloxacin for about a week now, since I was admitted to the medical floor with pneumonia. As for side effects, I did experience some nausea and stomach upset when I first started taking it, but that seemed to settle down after a few days.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me, how was your overall health before being admitted for pneumonia, and did you experience any symptoms prior to starting the levofloxacin? Also, I'd like to examine your abdomen right now. Can you please lift your shirt and let me take a look?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I was feeling pretty well before I got pneumonia. I had no major health issues, just the usual stuff like high blood pressure and high cholesterol. As for symptoms before starting the levofloxacin, I did have a bit of a cough and some fatigue, but it wasn't too bad.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your abdomen further. Can you please lift your shirt and let me take a look at your lower abdomen, just below your belly button? I'm looking for any tenderness or swelling. And, I'd like to request test results: REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count (CBC). This will help me understand if there's any infection or inflammation present in your body. Also, I'd like to ask, have you noticed any fever or chills associated with your symptoms of diarrhea?

speaker: Measurement
text: Abdominal_Examination: Diffuse mild tenderness in the lower abdomen, no guarding or rebound tenderness. Vital_Signs: Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F), Blood_Pressure: 122/98 mmHg, Heart_Rate: 67 bpm, Respiratory_Rate: 15 breaths/min. tests: Complete_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL, Total_Count_WBC: 13,400/mm3, Differential_Count: Neutrophils: 80%, Lymphocytes: 15%, Monocytes: 5%, ESR: 33 mm/hr.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the results of the Complete Blood Count, it appears that there is some mild inflammation present in your body, but nothing that would suggest a severe infection. The elevated ESR, however, does indicate some level of inflammation. Can you tell me, have you noticed any other symptoms beyond the diarrhea, abdominal pain, and cramping, such as headache, joint pain, or fatigue? Also, I'd like to request some additional test results: REQUEST TEST: Stool_Sample. This will help me determine if there's any bacterial or parasitic infection present in your stool.

speaker: Measurement
text: Abdominal_Examination: Diffuse mild tenderness in the lower abdomen, no guarding or rebound tenderness. Vital_Signs: Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F), Blood_Pressure: 122/98 mmHg, Heart_Rate: 67 bpm, Respiratory_Rate: 15 breaths/min. tests: Complete_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL, Total_Count_WBC: 13,400/mm3, Differential_Count: Neutrophils: 80%, Lymphocytes: 15%, Monocytes: 5%, ESR: 33 mm/hr. tests: Stool_Sample: Pending. Regarding your symptoms, you have reported diarrhea, abdominal pain, and cramping. You have not mentioned any other symptoms such as headache, joint pain, or fatigue.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request test results: REQUEST TEST: Stool_Sample. We need to determine if there's any bacterial or parasitic infection present in your stool. Also, I'd like to ask, have you noticed any other symptoms beyond the diarrhea, abdominal pain, and cramping, such as nausea or vomiting?

speaker: Measurement
text: Abdominal_Examination: Diffuse mild tenderness in the lower abdomen, no guarding or rebound tenderness. Vital_Signs: Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F), Blood_Pressure: 122/98 mmHg, Heart_Rate: 67 bpm, Respiratory_Rate: 15 breaths/min. tests: Complete_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL, Total_Count_WBC: 13,400/mm3, Differential_Count: Neutrophils: 80%, Lymphocytes: 15%, Monocytes: 5%, ESR: 33 mm/hr. tests: Stool_Sample: Watery, WBC_in_Stool: 10 white blood cells per high power field, Culture: Negative, Clostridium_difficile_Toxin: Negative.

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like we're getting closer to figuring out what's going on here. Can you tell me more about the berries you picked up from the market? Were they a specific type, like blueberries or strawberries? And, just to confirm, you're saying the stool sample culture and toxin tests came back negative for Clostridium difficile?

speaker: Patient
text: I just picked up a mix of berries, I didn't really notice the specific type. And yes, the tests did come back negative for Clostridium difficile, which was a bit of a relief, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request some additional test results: REQUEST TEST: Imaging of the small intestine, specifically a barium study. This will help us visualize the small intestine and see if there's any inflammation or damage. Also, can you tell me more about the mix of berries you picked up from the market? Were they a mix of fresh and frozen berries, or was it a mix of different types of berries?

speaker: Measurement
text: Abdominal_Examination: Diffuse mild tenderness in the lower abdomen, no guarding or rebound tenderness. Vital_Signs: Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F), Blood_Pressure: 122/98 mmHg, Heart_Rate: 67 bpm, Respiratory_Rate: 15 breaths/min. tests: Complete_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL, Total_Count_WBC: 13,400/mm3, Differential_Count: Neutrophils: 80%, Lymphocytes: 15%, Monocytes: 5%, ESR: 33 mm/hr. tests: Stool_Sample: Watery, WBC_in_Stool: 10 white blood cells per high power field, Culture: Negative, Clostridium_difficile_Toxin: Negative. Imaging of the small intestine: Barium study - Normal readings. No signs of inflammation or damage to the small intestine were observed.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me, how long have you been eating the berries you picked up from the market, and have you noticed any other symptoms besides the diarrhea and abdominal pain? Also, I'd like to request some additional test results: REQUEST TEST: Blood chemistry panel. This will help us understand if there are any underlying metabolic issues that might be contributing to your symptoms.

speaker: Measurement
text: Abdominal_Examination: Diffuse mild tenderness in the lower abdomen, no guarding or rebound tenderness. Vital_Signs: Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F), Blood_Pressure: 122/98 mmHg, Heart_Rate: 67 bpm, Respiratory_Rate: 15 breaths/min. tests: Complete_Blood_Count: Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL, Total_Count_WBC: 13,400/mm3, Differential_Count: Neutrophils: 80%, Lymphocytes: 15%, Monocytes: 5%, ESR: 33 mm/hr. tests: Stool_Sample: Watery, WBC_in_Stool: 10 white blood cells per high power field, Culture: Negative, Clostridium_difficile_Toxin: Negative. tests: Blood_Chemistry_Panel: Results:

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to review the blood chemistry panel results with you. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms besides the diarrhea and abdominal pain, such as nausea or vomiting, that might be related to your liver or kidney function?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been feeling a bit fatigued since I started taking the levofloxacin, but it's not too bad. I've also had a slight cough, but like I said, it wasn't too bad.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like the levofloxacin may have caused some fatigue and a slight cough. I'm going to take a closer look at the blood chemistry panel results to see if there's anything else that might be contributing to your symptoms. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms besides the diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fatigue? And, I'd like to request some additional test results: REQUEST TEST: Liver Function Tests (LFTs). This will help us understand if there's any liver damage or inflammation that might be contributing to your symptoms.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: Blood_Pressure: 122/98 mmHg, Heart_Rate: 67 bpm, Respiratory_Rate: 15 breaths/min. tests: Blood_Chemistry_Panel: Results: Albumin: 4.2 g/dL, Total_Bilirubin: 0.8 mg/dL, Alanine_Transaminase (ALT): 25 U/L, Aspartate_Transaminase (AST): 30 U/L, Alkaline_Phosphatase: 90 U/L, Gamma_Glutamyl_Transferase (GGT): 40 U/L.

speaker: Doctor
text: Based on the results of the blood chemistry panel, it appears that there is some mild elevation in liver enzymes, but nothing that would suggest significant liver damage. The albumin level is slightly low, which could be related to the recent antibiotic use, but it's not drastically low. I'd like to request some additional test results: REQUEST TEST: Liver Function Tests (LFTs) with a more detailed analysis of the liver enzymes. I'd also like to ask, have you noticed any other symptoms besides the diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fatigue, such as itching or jaundice? Also, I'd like to review the imaging results from the barium study. Are there any areas of the small intestine that appear more inflamed or irritated than others?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital_Signs: Blood_Pressure: 122/98 mmHg, Heart_Rate: 67 bpm, Respiratory_Rate: 15 breaths/min. tests: Liver_Function_Tests: Results: Alanine_Transaminase (ALT): 28 U/L, Aspartate_Transaminase (AST): 32 U/L, Alkaline_Phosphatase: 95 U/L, Gamma_Glutamyl_Transferase (GGT): 45 U/L.

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like we're getting closer to figuring out what's going on here. Can you tell me more about the mix of berries you picked up from the market? Were they a mix of fresh and frozen berries, or was it a mix of different types of berries? And, I'd like to review the imaging results from the barium study. Are there any areas of the small intestine that appear more inflamed or irritated than others?

speaker: Patient
text: I picked up a mix of fresh berries, not frozen. I got a variety pack, so it was a mix of blueberries, strawberries, raspberries, and blackberries. I washed them all before putting them in the fridge, but like I said, I didn't think twice about it afterwards.

speaker: Doctor

speaker: Doctor
text: DIAGNOSIS READY: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) with a possible food intolerance component. The patient's symptoms of diarrhea, abdominal pain, and cramping, along with the positive stool sample showing 10 white blood cells per high power field, suggest IBS. The negative results for Clostridium difficile toxin and the normal barium study results also point away from a bacterial infection. The mild elevation in liver enzymes and the patient's recent use of levofloxacin may be related to a food intolerance component, possibly related to the consumption of the mixed berries.
